newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia's Gazprom denies accounts frozen.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Gazprom denies accounts frozen.

text.p: Russian natural gas monopoly RAO Gazprom denied that accounts of its regional subsidiaries had been seized by the government.

"There is and has been no seizure of accounts. All Gazprom structures are continuing to work in a stable way, reliably providing gas for consumers at home and abroad," Gazprom's press service said in a statement.
Gazprom chairman Rem Vyakhirev said in a letter to parliament earlier this month that some of the company's assets had been frozen in an attempt to rake back unpaid taxes.

Gazprom, the world's biggest gas company, acknowledges it owes more than 15 trillion roubles ($2.8 billion) in taxes but says it is owed more than three times that amount by consumers, including the government.
But a Gazprom spokesman said a few days later the assertion that assets had been frozen should not be taken literally but was intended to make consumers pay their gas debts.
The whole Russian economy is mired in a non-payments crisis, in which many companies do not pay their suppliers, their workers or their taxes.

The government, trying to keep within the terms of a $10 billion International Monetary Fund (IMF) loan, has declared war on tax dodgers. A powerful presidential commission, headed by Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin has been set up to spearhead the effort.

"Gazprom does not have and has not had any conflict with the government. We have worked and will continue to work in maximum cooperation with the government to find a way out of the payments crisis, to resolve the problems of stabilising the socio-economic situation in the country," Gazprom said in its latest statement.
The confusion over Gazprom's assets has come at an embarrassing time for the company as it prepares an international stock offering.

Lead managers Morgan Stanley and Dresdner Kleinwort Benson said a week ago the preliminary price for a Gazprom American Depositary Share, each representing 10 ordinary shares, would be between $14 and $16. Gazprom shares opened at $0.30 on the Russian Trading System on Monday.
